Differentially Private AUC Computation
in Vertical Federated Learning

Jiankai Sun &Xin Yang &Yuanshun Yao &Junyuan Xie &Di Wu &Chong Wang Bytedance Inc. Corresponds to {jiankai.sun, chong.wang}@bytedance.com
Abstract

Federated learning has gained great attention recently as a privacy-enhancing tool to jointly train a machine learning model by multiple parties. As a sub-category, vertical federated learning (vFL) focuses on the scenario where features and labels are split into different parties. The prior work on vFL has mostly studied how to protect label privacy during model training. However, model evaluation in vFL might also lead to potential leakage of private label information. One mitigation strategy is to apply label differential privacy (DP) but it gives bad estimations of the true (non-private) metrics. In this work, we propose two evaluation algorithms that can more accurately compute the widely used AUC (area under curve) metric when using label DP in vFL. Through extensive experiments, we show our algorithms can achieve more accurate AUCs compared to the baselines.

1 Introduction

With increasing concerns over data privacy in machine learning, regulations like CCPA111California Consumer Privacy Act, HIPAA222Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act, and GDPR333General Data Protection Regulation, European Union have been introduced to regulate how data can be transmitted and used. To address privacy concerns, federated learningÂ [19, 14, 31, 11] has become an increasingly popular tool to enhance privacy by allowing training models without directly sharing their data. As a specific type of federated learning, vertical federated learning (vFL)Â [30, 12, 28] focuses on the application when the data is separately owned by multiple parties and each party holds either features or labels of the same data subjects. For example, in online advertisingÂ [17, 26], advertisers and the advertising platform (e.g. Google, Meta, and TikTok) can jointly train a model to predict the conversion rate (CVR) of an ad impression. In vFL protocol, the model is split layerwise and disjointly owned by advertisers and the platform, and the training and test are done by exchanging backward gradients and forward embeddings rather than the raw data. Therefore private information like user information (i.e. features) remains on the platform while the conversion events (i.e. labels) are kept to advertisers. We refer to the platform which only owns raw features and is in charge of the communication as the server, and the individual parties (advertisers) which own private labels as clients.

Despite the practical usefulness of vFL, researchers have shown that vFL can still leak data information indirectly. For example, Li et alÂ [17] demonstrate that the gradient updates between the server and client can leak label information. However, the prior work on vFL privacy mostly focuses on the model training and there can also be privacy leaked from model evaluation. Specifically, the private label information owned by clients can be leaked to the server when computing evaluation metrics. For example, Stoddard el al.Â [24] show that the server can simply guess the labels, plot the ROC curve, and compare it with the given ROC curve.

In this work, we focus on protecting label privacy when multiple parties jointly evaluate the trained vFL model. Specifically, we want to protect privacy when computing AUC. AUC is a widely used and standard metric; therefore it is a must when evaluating models. However, computing AUC in vFL while protecting label information is challenging because AUC requires sorting the testing samples by predicted score globally (i.e. from all clients) which is a procedure more complicated than other simpler metrics (e.g. test loss or accuracy). For example, the server can compute global test loss easily by simply asking all clients to send their local loss and then compute the global test loss as the weighted sum (weighted by the number of local samples). However, simply aggregating local AUC does not lead to the correct global AUC because the overall AUC requires global ranking.

To address the challenge, we leverage probabilistic interpretation of AUC related to Mann-Whitney U statisticsÂ [22, 4]. We view AUC as the probability of correct ranking of a random positive-negative pair and we can avoid requiring clients to send their labels to the server. Our goal is to achieve label differential privacyÂ [10] since the class label is often the most sensitive information in a prediction task. To this end, we propose two DP mechanisms. The first leverages randomized response to flip local labels in the clients, and then we debias the AUC computed with flipped labels. The second approach adopts the Laplace mechanism (Gaussian mechanism is applicable too) to add noise to the shared intermediate information between the server and clients to calculate the AUC. We conduct extensive experiments to demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed approaches.

2 Preliminaries

We start with introducing some background knowledge of our work.

2.1 Vertical Federated Learning

Training. The training of vFL includes forward pass and backward gradients computation. During the forward pass, the party without labels (server) sends the intermediate layer (cut layer) outputs rather than the raw data to the party with labels (clients), and the clients completes the rest of the forward computation to obtain the training loss. In the backward phase, to compute the gradients w.r.t model parameters, the client performs backpropagation from its training loss, computes its own parametersâ€™ gradients, and updates its own model. The client also computes the gradients w.r.t cut layer outputs and sends it to the server, and then server uses the chain rule to compute gradients of its model parameters, and update its model.

Inference. During inference time, the server computes the cut layer embedding and sends it to the clients. Clients then execute the rest of forward computation to compute the prediction probability.

We focus on the setting of multi-party vFL which contains one server and multi clients. The labels are distributed in multi clients and our proposed approaches can compute the evaluation metric AUC with label differential privacy.

2.2 Label Differential Privacy

2.3 ROC Curve and AUC

In a binary classification problem, given a threshold Î¸ğœƒ\theta, a predicted score sisubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–s_{i} is predicted to be 111 if siâ‰¥Î¸subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğœƒs_{i}\geq\theta. Given the ground-truth label and the predicted label (at a given threshold Î¸ğœƒ\theta), we can compute True Positive Rate (TPR) and False Positive Rate (FPR). TPR (i.e. recall) is defined as Tâ€‹Pâ€‹Râ€‹(Î¸)=Tâ€‹Pâ€‹(Î¸)Tâ€‹Pâ€‹(Î¸)+Fâ€‹Nâ€‹(Î¸)ğ‘‡ğ‘ƒğ‘…ğœƒğ‘‡ğ‘ƒğœƒğ‘‡ğ‘ƒğœƒğ¹ğ‘ğœƒTPR(\theta)=\frac{TP(\theta)}{TP(\theta)+FN(\theta)} and False Positive Rate (FPR) is defined as Fâ€‹Pâ€‹Râ€‹(Î¸)=Fâ€‹Pâ€‹(Î¸)Fâ€‹Pâ€‹(Î¸)+Tâ€‹Nâ€‹(Î¸)ğ¹ğ‘ƒğ‘…ğœƒğ¹ğ‘ƒğœƒğ¹ğ‘ƒğœƒğ‘‡ğ‘ğœƒFPR(\theta)=\frac{FP(\theta)}{FP(\theta)+TN(\theta)}. Receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve plots TPR (x-axis) vs. FPR (y-axis) over all possible thresholds Î¸ğœƒ\theta, and AUC is the area under the ROC curve. A perfect classifier has AUC 1.01.01.0 while a classifier giving random predictions has AUC 0.50.50.5.

Privacy Leakage in AUC. Researchers have shown AUC computation can cause privacy leakage. Matthews and HarelÂ [18] demonstrate that by using a subset of the ground-truth data and the computed ROC curve, the data underlying the ROC curve can be reproduced accurately. Stoddard el al.Â [24] show that an attacker can determine the unknown label by simply enumerating over all labels, guessing the labels, and then checking which guesses lead to the given ROC curve. They propose a differentially private ROC curve computation algorithm that adds DP noise to TPRs and FPRs.

2.4 Probabilistic Interpretation of AUC

Area under ROC curve (AUC) can be related to Mann-Whitney U statistics Â [22, 4] by viewing it as the probability of correct ranking of a random positive-negative pair. Suppose we have Mğ‘€M samples with Pğ‘ƒP positive and Nğ‘N negative samples, where M=P+Nğ‘€ğ‘ƒğ‘M=P+N. Given a classifier â„±â„±\mathcal{F} that outputs a prediction score sisubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–s_{i} for each sample with index iğ‘–i from 1 to Mğ‘€M. To compute AUC, we first sort all samples based on their prediction scores with an increasing order, i.e. each predicted score sisubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–s_{i} is assigned a rank risubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–r_{i} where ri=0subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–0r_{i}=0 indicates sample with index iğ‘–i has the lowest prediction score sisubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–s_{i} and where ri=Mâˆ’1subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘€1r_{i}=M-1 indicates the highest. Then AUC can be computed as the following:

AUC=âˆ‘i=1Mriâ‹…yiâˆ’Pâ€‹(Pâˆ’1)2Pâ€‹NAUCsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘€â‹…subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘ƒğ‘ƒ12ğ‘ƒğ‘\text{AUC}=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{M}r_{i}\cdot y_{i}-\frac{P(P-1)}{2}}{PN} (1)

where yiâˆˆ{0,1}subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–01y_{i}\in\{0,1\} is the ground-truth label for sample iğ‘–i. We include more details in Section Â H of the Appendix.

3 Threat Model

We formally define our scenario. In our vFL setting, there are multiple label parties (i.e. clients) that own private labels (i.e. Y)444they can also own some features and there is a central non-label party (i.e. server) that owns features and is responsible for computing global AUC from all clients. The model (early layers) owned by the server is shared by all clients, and each client owns its individual model (late layers) trained on their own private data. Before the training starts, the server and each client split their data into training and test set. The model is trained using the normal vFL protocol.

Our work focuses on the evaluation time and the goal of the server is to compute global AUC without letting clients directly share their private test data. In other words, clients cannot directly send the test data (i.e. private labels) to the server for it to compute AUC. Specifically, we are interested in protecting label information and therefore it is required that the exchanged information between client and server excludes the ground-truth test labels (Y).

Note that the exchanged information might contain some indirect information that can be used by the server to infer clientsâ€™ test labels (Y), e.g. the predicted score fâ€‹(X)ğ‘“ğ‘‹f(X), which we assume to be considered non-sensitive by nature of the task. For example, in online advertising, clients (i.e. advertisers) have to send the predicted scores, i.e. predicted conversion rate (CVR), to the server (i.e. advertising platforms like Google, Meta, or Tiktok) so that the server can compute the bid priceÂ [23]. In this case, the predicted scores have to be shared with the server in order to perform the task, and clients have already agreed to share them before participating in vFL. We include more discussion on the privacy sensitivity of predicted scores in SectionÂ R in the Appendix.

4 Proposed Algorithm 1: Randomized Response Mechanism

We introduce our first algorithm to compute AUC when applying label DP to vFL for evaluation. The algorithm is based on randomized responseÂ [29] and we name it as FedAUCRRsubscriptFedAUCRR\text{FedAUC}_{\text{RR}}. We include the workflow in Figure Â 2 in the Appendix. We now explain the algorithm step by step.

4.1 Step 1: Clients Flip Their Local Labels

Randomized response (RR) is Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-LabelDP and works as following: let Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon be a parameter and let yâˆˆ{0,1}ğ‘¦01y\in\{0,1\} be the true label. Given a query of yğ‘¦y, RR will respond with a random draw y~~ğ‘¦\tilde{y} from the following probability distribution:

Prâ¡[y~=y^]={eÏµ1+eÏµforÂ y=y^,11+eÏµotherwise.Pr~ğ‘¦^ğ‘¦casessuperscriptğ‘’italic-Ïµ1superscriptğ‘’italic-ÏµforÂ y=y^,11superscriptğ‘’italic-Ïµotherwise.\Pr[\tilde{y}=\hat{y}]=\begin{cases}\frac{e^{\epsilon}}{1+e^{\epsilon}}&\text{for $y=\hat{y}$,}\\ \frac{1}{1+e^{\epsilon}}&\text{otherwise.}\end{cases} (2)

Clients can leverage randomized response (Algorithm Â 1 in the Appendix) to flip their owning labels as a preprocessing step before computing the AUC. Itâ€™s worth mentioning that all labels are only flipped once and the generated noisy labels can then be used for further evaluations multi-times.

4.3 Step 3: Server Debiases AUC

Section Â 4.2 shows how the server compute AUCDnoisysuperscriptAUCsubscriptğ·noisy\text{AUC}^{D_{\text{noisy}}} with using clientsâ€™ local flipped labels. 5 Proposed Algorithm 2: Laplace and Gaussian Mechanism

In this section, we introduce how to compute the AUC with label differential privacy by leveraging Laplace and Gaussian mechanism. Here we use Laplace mechanism as an example. Other settings for the Gaussian mechanism will be the same.

5.1 Overall Workflow

The workflow of this method is as shown in Figure Â 3 in the appendix and the detailed Algorithm is shown in Algorithm Â 4 in the Appendix. The algorithm has four steps (the first two steps are the same as FedAUCRRsubscriptFedAUCRR\text{FedAUC}_{\text{RR}}):

  1. 1.

    Clients Execute. Each client Cksubscriptğ¶ğ‘˜C_{k} computes the prediction scores sk=fâ€‹(Xk)subscriptğ‘ ğ‘˜ğ‘“subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘˜s_{k}=f(X_{k}) for all its owning data points and sends shuffled sksuperscriptğ‘ ğ‘˜s^{k} to the server.

  2. 2.

    Server Executes. The server aggregates all the prediction scores and sort them in an increasing order. Each prediction score siksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘˜s_{i}^{k} (iâˆˆ[1,M]ğ‘–1ğ‘€i\in[1,M]) will be assigned a ranking order riksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘˜r_{i}^{k}. The server sends each ranking order riksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘˜r_{i}^{k} back to the corresponding client Cksubscriptğ¶ğ‘˜C_{k} which owns siksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘˜s_{i}^{k}.

  3. 3.

    Clients Execute. Each client Cksubscriptğ¶ğ‘˜C_{k} then aggregates all its received ranking orders with its label. The client also computes its number of positive (localP) and negative (localN) instances respectively. Here localP=âˆ‘i|Yk|yilocalPsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–\text{localP}=\sum_{i}^{|{Y_{k}}|}{y_{i}} and localN=âˆ‘i|Yk|(1âˆ’yi)localNsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–\text{localN}=\sum_{i}^{|{Y_{k}}|}(1-{y_{i}}). Each client Cksubscriptğ¶ğ‘˜C_{k} adds noise to localSumksubscriptlocalSumğ‘˜\text{localSum}_{k} and localPksubscriptlocalPğ‘˜\text{localP}_{k} to get localSumkâ€²superscriptsubscriptlocalSumğ‘˜â€²\text{localSum}_{k}^{\prime} and localPkâ€²superscriptsubscriptlocalPğ‘˜â€²\text{localP}_{k}^{\prime} respectively. The client Cksubscriptğ¶ğ‘˜C_{k} sends localSumkâ€²superscriptsubscriptlocalSumğ‘˜â€²\text{localSum}_{k}^{\prime}, localPkâ€²superscriptsubscriptlocalPğ‘˜â€²\text{localP}_{k}^{\prime}, and localNkâ€²superscriptsubscriptlocalNğ‘˜â€²\text{localN}_{k}^{\prime} (localNkâ€²=|Yk|âˆ’localPkâ€²superscriptsubscriptlocalNğ‘˜â€²subscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptlocalPğ‘˜â€²\text{localN}_{k}^{\prime}=|Y_{k}|-\text{localP}_{k}^{\prime}) to the server. We talk about how to add noises to these local statistics in Section Â 5.2.

  4. 4.

    Server Executes. After receiving all clientsâ€™ localSumâ€²superscriptlocalSumâ€²\text{localSum}^{\prime}, localPâ€²superscriptlocalPâ€²\text{localP}^{\prime} and localNâ€²superscriptlocalNâ€²\text{localN}^{\prime}, the server aggregates them to get the corresponding global values. The server then leverages equation Â (1) to compute the AUC. The final AUC is: AUC=globalSumâˆ’PÂ¯â€‹(PÂ¯âˆ’1)/2PÂ¯â€‹NÂ¯AUCglobalSumÂ¯ğ‘ƒÂ¯ğ‘ƒ12Â¯ğ‘ƒÂ¯ğ‘\text{AUC}=\frac{{\text{globalSum}-{\bar{P}(\bar{P}-1)}/{2}}}{{\bar{P}\bar{N}}}.

5.2 Adding Noise to Local Statistics

We explain in details how to perturb localSum and localP for each client in the algorithm. Both Gaussian and Laplace mechanisms can be leveraged to generate the corresponding DP noise. Without loss of generality, we use Laplace as an example. Laplace mechanism preserves (Ïµ,0)italic-Ïµ0(\epsilon,0)-differential privacy if the random noise is drawn from Lâ€‹aâ€‹pâ€‹(Î”/Ïµ)ğ¿ğ‘ğ‘Î”italic-ÏµLap(\Delta/\epsilon) where Î”Î”\Delta is the l1subscriptğ‘™1l_{1} sensitivity. We name this method as FedAUCLapsubscriptFedAUCLap\text{FedAUC}_{\text{Lap}}. The noise is added as the following:

  1. 1.

    Adding noise to localSum: Each client Cksubscriptğ¶ğ‘˜C_{k} decides its own sensitivity by selecting its maximum ranking order as Î”localSumk=maxiâˆˆ[1,|Yk|]â¡(rik)subscriptÎ”superscriptlocalSumğ‘˜subscriptğ‘–1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘˜\Delta_{\text{localSum}^{k}}=\max_{i\in[1,|Y_{k}|]}(r_{i}^{k}). Given a privacy budget Ïµlâ€‹oâ€‹câ€‹aâ€‹lâ€‹Sâ€‹uâ€‹msubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘†ğ‘¢ğ‘š\epsilon_{localSum}, client Cksubscriptğ¶ğ‘˜C_{k} draws the random noise from Lapâ€‹(Î”localSumk/Ïµlâ€‹oâ€‹câ€‹aâ€‹lâ€‹Sâ€‹uâ€‹m)LapsubscriptÎ”superscriptlocalSumğ‘˜subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘†ğ‘¢ğ‘š\textsf{Lap}(\Delta_{\text{localSum}^{k}}/\epsilon_{localSum}).

  2. 2.

    Adding noise to localP: Each client Cksubscriptğ¶ğ‘˜C_{k} sets Î”localPk=1subscriptÎ”superscriptlocalPğ‘˜1\Delta_{\text{localP}^{k}}=1. Given a privacy budget Ïµlâ€‹oâ€‹câ€‹aâ€‹lâ€‹Psubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘ƒ\epsilon_{localP}, client Cksubscriptğ¶ğ‘˜C_{k} draws the random noise from Lapâ€‹(1/Ïµlâ€‹oâ€‹câ€‹aâ€‹lâ€‹P)Lap1subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘ƒ\textsf{Lap}(1/\epsilon_{localP}).

Privacy Analysis. The total privacy budget Ïµ=Ïµlâ€‹oâ€‹câ€‹aâ€‹lâ€‹Sâ€‹uâ€‹m+Ïµlâ€‹oâ€‹câ€‹aâ€‹lâ€‹Pitalic-Ïµsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘†ğ‘¢ğ‘šsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘ƒ\epsilon=\epsilon_{localSum}+\epsilon_{localP}. We use a parameter Î±ğ›¼\alpha to control the budget allocation: Ïµlâ€‹oâ€‹câ€‹aâ€‹lâ€‹Sâ€‹uâ€‹m=Î±â€‹Ïµsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘†ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ›¼italic-Ïµ\epsilon_{localSum}=\alpha\epsilon and Ïµlâ€‹oâ€‹câ€‹aâ€‹lâ€‹P=(1âˆ’Î±)â€‹Ïµsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘ƒ1ğ›¼italic-Ïµ\epsilon_{localP}=(1-\alpha)\epsilon. Next we explain a a better allocation than using Î±ğ›¼\alpha.

5.3 Adaptive Allocation of DP Budget

Finding Î±ğ›¼\alpha that achieves a good tradeoff between utility and privacy can be difficult and would require many trials and errors if using cross validation. Therefore we propose an algorithm that automatically determines the allocation of the DP budget adaptively on each client.

Our inspiration comes from the special case where each client only owns 1 sample, i.e., |Yk|=1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜1|Y_{k}|=1 for each client Cksubscriptğ¶ğ‘˜C_{k}. In this case, it turns out that localSumk=rkâ‹…localPksubscriptlocalSumğ‘˜â‹…superscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘˜subscriptlocalPğ‘˜\text{localSum}_{k}=r^{k}\cdot\text{localP}_{k}. Since rksuperscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘˜r^{k} is public, we do not need to generate two independent random variables; we can sample sâˆ¼ğ–«ğ–ºğ—‰â€‹(1/Ïµ)similar-toğ‘ ğ–«ğ–ºğ—‰1italic-Ïµs\sim\mathsf{Lap}(1/\epsilon), and report localPkâ€²:=localPk+sassignsuperscriptsubscriptlocalPğ‘˜â€²subscriptlocalPğ‘˜ğ‘ \text{localP}_{k}^{\prime}:=\text{localP}_{k}+s and localSumkâ€²:=rkâ‹…localPkâ€²assignsuperscriptsubscriptlocalSumğ‘˜â€²â‹…superscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptlocalPğ‘˜â€²\text{localSum}_{k}^{\prime}:=r^{k}\cdot\text{localP}_{k}^{\prime}.

The above example shows that when localSumksubscriptlocalSumğ‘˜\text{localSum}_{k} and localPksubscriptlocalPğ‘˜\text{localP}_{k} are highly correlated, then the privacy budget can be allocated more efficiently. Based on this observation, we can analyze the general case. Fix the client Cksubscriptğ¶ğ‘˜C_{k}. Let ğ²:=(y1,â‹¯,y|Yk|)âˆˆ{0,1}|Yk|assignğ²subscriptğ‘¦1â‹¯subscriptğ‘¦subscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜superscript01subscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜\mathbf{y}:=(y_{1},\cdots,y_{|Y_{k}|})\in\{0,1\}^{|Y_{k}|} be the labels held by Cksubscriptğ¶ğ‘˜C_{k}, and ğ«:=(r1k,â‹¯,r|Yk|k)âˆˆâ„¤|Yk|assignğ«superscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘˜â‹¯superscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜ğ‘˜superscriptâ„¤subscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜\mathbf{r}:=(r_{1}^{k},\cdots,r_{|Y_{k}|}^{k})\in\mathbb{Z}^{|Y_{k}|} be their rankings. Then we have localPk=âŸ¨ğ®,ğ²âŸ©subscriptlocalPğ‘˜ğ®ğ²\text{localP}_{k}=\langle\mathbf{u},\mathbf{y}\rangle and localSumk=âŸ¨ğ«,ğ²âŸ©subscriptlocalSumğ‘˜ğ«ğ²\text{localSum}_{k}=\langle\mathbf{r},\mathbf{y}\rangle, where ğ®:=(1,1,â‹¯,1)assignğ®11â‹¯1\mathbf{u}:=(1,1,\cdots,1) is the all-one vector.

When ğ®ğ®\mathbf{u} and ğ«ğ«\mathbf{r} are parallel, namely ğ«=râ‹…ğ®ğ«â‹…ğ‘Ÿğ®\mathbf{r}=r\cdot\mathbf{u} for some râˆˆâ„ğ‘Ÿâ„r\in\mathbb{R}, we can still allocate all the budget on localPkâ€²superscriptsubscriptlocalPğ‘˜â€²\text{localP}_{k}^{\prime}, and report localSumkâ€²=râ‹…localPkâ€²superscriptsubscriptlocalSumğ‘˜â€²â‹…ğ‘ŸsuperscriptsubscriptlocalPğ‘˜â€²\text{localSum}_{k}^{\prime}=r\cdot\text{localP}_{k}^{\prime}. Then we have

localSumk=âŸ¨ğ«,ğ²âŸ©=âŸ¨ğ®â€²,ğ²âŸ©+âŸ¨ğ¯â€²,ğ²âŸ©.subscriptlocalSumğ‘˜ğ«ğ²superscriptğ®â€²ğ²superscriptğ¯â€²ğ²\displaystyle\text{localSum}_{k}=\langle\mathbf{r},\mathbf{y}\rangle=\langle\mathbf{u^{\prime}},\mathbf{y}\rangle+\langle\mathbf{v^{\prime}},\mathbf{y}\rangle.

In order to make (localPk,localSumk)subscriptlocalPğ‘˜subscriptlocalSumğ‘˜(\text{localP}_{k},\text{localSum}_{k}) Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-DP, by the post-processing property of differential privacy, it is sufficient to have (âŸ¨ğ®â€²,yâŸ©,âŸ¨ğ¯â€²,yâŸ©)superscriptğ®â€²ğ‘¦superscriptğ¯â€²ğ‘¦(\langle\mathbf{u}^{\prime},y\rangle,\langle\mathbf{v}^{\prime},y\rangle) to be Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-DP. If we use Laplace mechanism, this means we sample s1âˆ¼ğ–«ğ–ºğ—‰â€‹(1/(Î²â€‹Ïµ))similar-tosubscriptğ‘ 1ğ–«ğ–ºğ—‰1ğ›½italic-Ïµs_{1}\sim\mathsf{Lap}(1/(\beta\epsilon)) and s2âˆ¼ğ–«ğ–ºğ—‰â€‹(1/((1âˆ’Î²)â€‹Ïµ))similar-tosubscriptğ‘ 2ğ–«ğ–ºğ—‰11ğ›½italic-Ïµs_{2}\sim\mathsf{Lap}(1/((1-\beta)\epsilon)), and report localPkâ€²:=âŸ¨ğ®,yâŸ©+s1assignsuperscriptsubscriptlocalPğ‘˜â€²ğ®ğ‘¦subscriptğ‘ 1\text{localP}_{k}^{\prime}:=\langle\mathbf{u},y\rangle+s_{1}, localSumkâ€²:=âŸ¨ğ®â€²,yâŸ©+â€–ğ®â€²â€–âˆâ‹…s1+âŸ¨ğ¯â€²,yâŸ©+â€–ğ¯â€²â€–âˆâ‹…s2assignsuperscriptsubscriptlocalSumğ‘˜â€²superscriptğ®â€²ğ‘¦â‹…subscriptnormsuperscriptğ®â€²subscriptğ‘ 1superscriptğ¯â€²ğ‘¦â‹…subscriptnormsuperscriptğ¯â€²subscriptğ‘ 2\text{localSum}_{k}^{\prime}:=\langle\mathbf{u}^{\prime},y\rangle+\|\mathbf{u}^{\prime}\|_{\infty}\cdot s_{1}+\langle\mathbf{v}^{\prime},y\rangle+\|\mathbf{v}^{\prime}\|_{\infty}\cdot s_{2}.

We can tune the parameter Î²ğ›½\beta to achieve small standard deviation of estimated AUC. However, the server may need additional validation data to select a optimal Î²ğ›½\beta which performs the best. Sometimes, it is impractical in the setting of FL. We now show how to adaptively choose the allocation parameter Î²ğ›½\beta for each client. Simply, we use the heuristic of choosing Î²ğ›½\beta that minimizes the variance of localSumkâ€²superscriptsubscriptlocalSumğ‘˜â€²\text{localSum}_{k}^{\prime} for client kğ‘˜k, which is equivalent to minimizing the variance of â€–ğ®â€²â€–âˆâ‹…s1+â€–ğ¯â€²â€–âˆâ‹…s2â‹…subscriptnormsuperscriptğ®â€²subscriptğ‘ 1â‹…subscriptnormsuperscriptğ¯â€²subscriptğ‘ 2\|\mathbf{u}^{\prime}\|_{\infty}\cdot s_{1}+\|\mathbf{v}^{\prime}\|_{\infty}\cdot s_{2}.

6 Experiments

In this section, we show the experimental results of evaluating our proposed approaches.

6.1 Experimental Setup

Dataset. We evaluate the proposed approaches on CriteoÂ 555https://www.kaggle.com/c/criteo-display-ad-challenge/data, which is a large-scale industrial binary classification dataset (with with approximately 454545 million user click records) for conversion prediction tasks. We computed the AUC on the test set which contains M=458,407ğ‘€458407M=458,407 where P=117,317ğ‘ƒ117317P=117,317 and N=341,090ğ‘341090N=341,090 for 333 epochs.

Model. We modified a popular deep learning model architecture WDL [5] for online advertising. Note that our goal is not to train the model that can beat the state-of-the-art, but to test the effectiveness of our proposed federated AUC computation approach.

Ground-truth AUC. We compare our proposed FedAUC with two AUC computation libraries (their computed results work as ground-truth and have no privacy guarantee): 1) scikit-learn666https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.metrics.auc.html; 2) Tensorflow 777https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/keras/metrics/AUC. Both approximate the AUC (Area under the curve) of the ROC. In our experiments, we set num_thresholds=1,000num_thresholds1000\text{num\_thresholds}=1,000 for Tensorflow. We use the default values for other parameters.

Evaluation Metric. For each method, we run the same setting for 100100100 times (change the random seed every time) and use the corresponding standard deviation of the computed AUC as our evaluation metric888We only include the standard deviation of computed AUCs rather than the mean because we find that the mean of our AUCs is close to the ground-truth AUC. See the results of mean AUC in TableÂ 5 and Â 6 in the Appendix.. A good computation method should achieve a small std of the computed AUC.

6.2 Experimental Results

6.2.1 Results of FedAUCRRsubscriptFedAUCRR\text{FedAUC}_{\text{RR}}

Effectiveness of FedAUCRRsubscriptFedAUCRR\text{FedAUC}_{\text{RR}}. We report the standard deviation of the AUC estimated by FedAUCRRsubscriptFedAUCRR\text{FedAUC}_{\text{RR}} with different Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon in Table Â 1. We put more detailed results in Table Â 5 and Â 7 in the Appendix. We can observe that vanilla FedAUCRRsubscriptFedAUCRR\text{FedAUC}_{\text{RR}} (with Ïµ=+âˆitalic-Ïµ\epsilon=+\infty and Ï+=Ïâˆ’=0subscriptğœŒsubscriptğœŒ0\rho_{+}=\rho_{-}=0) which has no DP guarantee can achieve almost the same value as the ones computed by scikit-learn and Tensorflow. The corresponding results demonstrated the correctness and effectiveness of FedAUCRRsubscriptFedAUCRR\text{FedAUC}_{\text{RR}}. Results in Table Â 3 in the Appendix shows the results without debiasing as we described in Section Â 4.3, which demonstrates that converting the noisy AUC to the clean AUC is badly needed.

Impact of data size. We also tested the effectiveness of FedAUCRRsubscriptFedAUCRR\text{FedAUC}_{\text{RR}} on a larger evaluation set which has 4,584,062 data samples which is 10 times larger than the small one. The detailed statistics of these two dataset can be seen in Table Â 4 in the Appendix. As shown in Table Â 6 (in the Appendix) and Figure Â 1 (a), the AUC on the large dataset is approximately 1/101101/\sqrt{10} of the value achieved on the small dataset with the same privacy budget Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. It indicates that increasing the dataset size can reduce the standard deviation of the estimated AUC. The same conclusion is applicable to FedAUCLapsubscriptFedAUCLap\text{FedAUC}_{\text{Lap}} too.

6.2.2 Results of FedAUCLapsubscriptFedAUCLap\text{FedAUC}_{\text{Lap}}

Both Gaussian and Laplace mechanism can be use in FedAUCLapsubscriptFedAUCLap\text{FedAUC}_{\text{Lap}}. In our experiments, we adopt Laplace mechanism as an example to show the effectiveness of our proposed technique. We refer this technique as LocalLaplace. We also add a comparison partner GocalLaplace here. All clients use Mâˆ’1ğ‘€1M-1 as the sensitivity when adding noise to their local statistics localSum. Given a privacy budget Ïµlâ€‹oâ€‹câ€‹aâ€‹lâ€‹Sâ€‹uâ€‹msubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘†ğ‘¢ğ‘š\epsilon_{localSum}, client Cksubscriptğ¶ğ‘˜C_{k} draws the random noise from Lâ€‹aâ€‹pâ€‹((Mâˆ’1)/Ïµlâ€‹oâ€‹câ€‹aâ€‹lâ€‹Sâ€‹uâ€‹m)ğ¿ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘€1subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘†ğ‘¢ğ‘šLap((M-1)/\epsilon_{localSum}). Each client adds the same amount of noise to its localSum. Ïµlâ€‹oâ€‹câ€‹aâ€‹lâ€‹Psubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘ƒ\epsilon_{localP} is kept the same as LocalLaplace.

Unlike FedAUCRRsubscriptFedAUCRR\text{FedAUC}_{\text{RR}}, FedAUCLapsubscriptFedAUCLap\text{FedAUC}_{\text{Lap}} is sensitive to the number of clients and number of samples per client has. Based on the setting of how to assign data sample to clients, we provide two simulations to conduct the corresponding experiments.

  1. 1.

    IID: all data points are uniformly assigned to the clients.

  2. 2.

    Non-IID: all data points are assigned to the clients based on their corresponding prediction scores. Data samples with similar prediction scores will be assigned to the same client.

We divide Mğ‘€M data samples into Kğ¾K clients based on the IID and Non-IID settings and each client has MKğ‘€ğ¾\frac{M}{K} data samples on average. We also provide an extreme scenario to simply our analysis: each client only has one data sample (M=Kğ‘€ğ¾M=K). Under this setting and suppose we use accurate Pğ‘ƒP and Nğ‘N to compute the AUC, we can conclude from Equation 8 and 9 (both in the Appendix) that: AUCglobalLaplaceAUClocalLaplaceâ‰ˆ3subscriptAUCglobalLaplacesubscriptAUClocalLaplace3\frac{\text{AUC}_{\text{globalLaplace}}}{\text{AUC}_{\text{localLaplace}}}\approx\sqrt{3}. Our results as shown in Table Â 2 (in the Appendix) verified this observation.

Sensitivity of Î±ğ›¼\alpha. We conduct experiments to check the sensitivity of Î±ğ›¼\alpha for FedAUCLapsubscriptFedAUCLap\text{FedAUC}_{\text{Lap}}. Given a total DP budget Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon, Ïµlâ€‹oâ€‹câ€‹aâ€‹lâ€‹Sâ€‹uâ€‹m=Î±â€‹Ïµsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘†ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ›¼italic-Ïµ\epsilon_{localSum}=\alpha\epsilon and Ïµlâ€‹oâ€‹câ€‹aâ€‹lâ€‹P=(1âˆ’Î±â€‹Ïµ)subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘ƒ1ğ›¼italic-Ïµ\epsilon_{localP}=(1-\alpha\epsilon). We assign the data samples uniformly to 1,00010001,000 clients (IID setting) and on average each client has 458 data samples. The corresponding results are shown in Figure Â 1 (b). It shows that when Î±âˆˆ[0.5,0.6]ğ›¼0.50.6\alpha\in[0.5,0.6], the corresponding standard deviation of AUC estimation is the smallest. Hence, for the following experiments, we set Î±=0.5ğ›¼0.5\alpha=0.5. Other settings (i.e. Non-IID and different number of clients) share the same pattern. To save space, we put the corresponding results in the Appendix as shown in Figure Â 4 and Â 5.

Advantages of Adaptive Allocation. We conduct some experiments to show the advantages of orthogonalization and corresponding adaptive allocation. Given the total DP budget Ïµ=1italic-Ïµ1\epsilon=1, we assign 1,00010001,000 Non-IID samples to each client. We compared another approach which only does orthogonalization (without adaptive allocation). We tune the corresponding allocation parameter Î²ğ›½\beta and let each client share the same Î²ğ›½\beta. The corresponding result is shown in Figure Â 1 (c) with legend "Orthogonal". It can achieve a smaller standard deviation than the naive one (tuning Î±ğ›¼\alpha for FedAUCLapsubscriptFedAUCLap\text{FedAUC}_{\text{Lap}}). The legend "Adaptive" in in Figure Â 1 (c) represents that each client adaptive allocates the DP budget and hence it should be a point in the figure. To make a better comparison with "Naive" and "Orthogonal", we show a horizontal line in the figure for "Adaptive" instead. Adaptive allocation can achieve the smallest standard deviation of AUC, which demonstrates the effectiveness of adaptive allocation. Similar results on the IID setting can be seen in the Figure Â 6. The distribution of the adaptive allocated parameter Î²ğ›½\beta for all clients can be seen in Figure Â 8 in the Appendix.

RR vs. GlobalLaplace vs. LocalLaplace (w/wo. adaptive allocation). We now compare our proposed methods (RR, GlobalLaplace, and LocalLaplace (w/wo adaptive allocation)) in Table 7 with different settings (i.e. different number of clients and different privacy budget Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon). We set the DP budget allocation parameter Î±=0.5ğ›¼0.5\alpha=0.5 for LocalLaplace without adaptive allocation. It shows that RR can gain some advantages when the avg. ##\# data samples per client is small. However, with increasing avg. ##\# data samples per client, LocalLaplace can achieve smaller standard deviation of AUC estimation since it adds smaller amounts of noise than RR and GlobalLaplace. LocalLaplace with adaptive allocation can perform the best under most of the cases.

7 Related Work

Federated Learning. FLÂ [19, 30] can be mainly classified into three categories: horizontal FL, vFL, and federated transfer learning Â [30]. When the jointly trained model is a neural network, the setting is the same as split learning such as SplitNN Â [28].

Information Leakage in vFL. Recently, studies show that in vFL, even though the raw data (feature and label) is not shared, sensitive information can still be leaked from the gradients and intermediate embeddings communicated between parties. For example, [27] and [26] showed that serverâ€™s raw features can be leaked from the forward cut layer embedding. In addition, [17] studied the label leakage problem but the leakage source was the backward gradients rather than forward embeddings.

Information Protection in vFL. There are three main categories of information protection techniques in vFL: 1) cryptographic methods such as secure multi-party computation [3]; 2) system-based methods including trusted execution environments [25]; and 3) perturbation methods that add noise to the communicated messagesÂ [1, 20, 8, 6, 32]. In this paper, we focus on adding DP noise to protect the private label information during computing AUC.

8 Conclusion

We propose two label DP algorithms to compute AUC when evaluating models in vFL protocol. Through experiments, we find our algorithms can estimate AUCs accurately. We primarily focus on the online advertising scenario when the predicted scores are not considered as sensitive, and we leave the generalization to other scenarios for future work. We hope our work can bring more attention to the current vFL literature on how to protect privacy when evaluating models.

Appendix H Computing AUC from a probabilistic perspective

In a binary classification problem, given a threshold Î¸ğœƒ\theta, a predicted score sisubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–s_{i} is predicted to be 111 if siâ‰¥Î¸subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğœƒs_{i}\geq\theta. Given the ground-truth label and the predicted label (at a given threshold Î¸ğœƒ\theta), we can quantify the accuracy of the classifier on the dataset with True positives (TP(Î¸ğœƒ\theta)), False positives (FP(Î¸ğœƒ\theta)), False negatives (FN(Î¸ğœƒ\theta)), and True negatives (TN(Î¸ğœƒ\theta)). Area under the Receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves plots two variables: True Positive Rate (TPR) False Positive Rate (FPR). TPR (i.e. recall) is defined as Tâ€‹Pâ€‹Râ€‹(Î¸)=Tâ€‹Pâ€‹(Î¸)Tâ€‹Pâ€‹(Î¸)+Fâ€‹Nâ€‹(Î¸)ğ‘‡ğ‘ƒğ‘…ğœƒğ‘‡ğ‘ƒğœƒğ‘‡ğ‘ƒğœƒğ¹ğ‘ğœƒTPR(\theta)=\frac{TP(\theta)}{TP(\theta)+FN(\theta)}. False Positive Rate (FPR) is defined as (Î¸)=Fâ€‹Pâ€‹(Î¸)Fâ€‹Pâ€‹(Î¸)+Tâ€‹Nâ€‹(Î¸)ğœƒğ¹ğ‘ƒğœƒğ¹ğ‘ƒğœƒğ‘‡ğ‘ğœƒ(\theta)=\frac{FP(\theta)}{FP(\theta)+TN(\theta)}.

  • â€¢

    True positives, TP(Î¸ğœƒ\theta), are the data points in test whose true label and predicted label equals 111. i.e. yi=1subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–1y_{i}=1 and siâ‰¥Î¸subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğœƒs_{i}\geq\theta

  • â€¢

    False positives, FP(Î¸ğœƒ\theta), are the data points in test whose true label is 00 but the predicted label is 111. i.e. yi=0subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–0y_{i}=0 and siâ‰¥Î¸subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğœƒs_{i}\geq\theta.

  • â€¢

    False negatives, FN(Î¸ğœƒ\theta), are data points whose true label is 111 but the predicted label is 00. i.e. yi=1subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–1y_{i}=1 and si<Î¸subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğœƒs_{i}<\theta.

  • â€¢

    True negatives, TN(Î¸ğœƒ\theta), are data points whose true label is 00 and the predicted label is 00. i.e. yi=0subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–0y_{i}=0 and si<Î¸subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğœƒs_{i}<\theta.

The ROC curve is defined by plotting pairs of FPR(Î¸ğœƒ\theta) (x-axis) versus TPR(Î¸ğœƒ\theta) (y-axis) over all possible thresholds Î¸ğœƒ\theta. ROC curve starts at (0,0)00(0,0) and ends at (1,1)11(1,1). The area under the ROC curve (AUC) is used to evaluate the performance of a binary classifier. If the classifier is good, the ROC curve will be close to the left and upper boundary and AUC will be close to 1.01.01.0. On the other hand, if the classifier is poor, the ROC curve will be close to line from (0,0)00(0,0) to (1,1)11(1,1) with AUC around 0.50.50.5.

H.1 Computing AUC with Time Complexity O(PN)

Area under ROC curve (AUC) is well studied in statistics and is equivalent to Mann-Whitney U statistics Â [22, 4]. We focus on computing the AUC by viewing it as the probability of correct ranking of a random positive-negative pair. Suppose we have Mğ‘€M samples including Pğ‘ƒP positives and Nğ‘N negatives, where M=P+Nğ‘€ğ‘ƒğ‘M=P+N. Given a classifier â„±â„±\mathcal{F}, it gives a prediction score sisubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–s_{i} for each sample iâˆˆ[1,M]ğ‘–1ğ‘€i\in[1,M]. We then have Mâ€‹Nğ‘€ğ‘MN positive-negative pairs with score <si,sj><s_{i},s_{j}> (iâˆˆ[1,M]ğ‘–1ğ‘€i\in[1,M] and jâˆˆ[1,N]ğ‘—1ğ‘j\in[1,N]) where sisubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–s_{i} and sjsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘—s_{j} are prediction scores of positive sample iğ‘–i and negative sample jğ‘—j respectively. Then AUC of classifier â„±â„±\mathcal{F} is:

AUC=I(<si,sj>)Mâ€‹N,iâˆˆ[1,M]andjâˆˆ[1,N]\text{AUC}=\frac{I(<s_{i},s_{j}>)}{MN},i\in[1,M]\quad\text{and}\quad j\in[1,N] (5)

where

I(<si,sj>)={1,ifsi>sj,0,oâ€‹tâ€‹hâ€‹eâ€‹râ€‹wâ€‹iâ€‹sâ€‹e.I(<s_{i},s_{j}>)=\begin{cases}1,\text{if}\quad s_{i}>s_{j},\\ 0,otherwise.\end{cases}

The time complexity of computing AUC is Oâ€‹(Pâ€‹N)ğ‘‚ğ‘ƒğ‘O(PN).

H.2 Computing AUC with Time Complexity Oâ€‹(Mâ€‹logâ¡M)ğ‘‚ğ‘€ğ‘€O(M\log M)

We firstly rank all instances based on their prediction scores in an increasing order. Each score sisubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–s_{i} (iâˆˆ[1,M]ğ‘–1ğ‘€i\in[1,M]) will be assigned a ranking risubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–r_{i}. The instance with the highest order will be assigned r=Mâˆ’1ğ‘Ÿğ‘€1r=M-1, and the second highest one will be assigned Mâˆ’2ğ‘€2M-2 and so on. The smallest ranking score is r=0ğ‘Ÿ0r=0.

Then AUC can be computed as:

AUC=âˆ‘i=1Mriâ‹…yiâˆ’Pâ€‹(Pâˆ’1)2Pâ€‹NAUCsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘€â‹…subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘ƒğ‘ƒ12ğ‘ƒğ‘\text{AUC}=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{M}r_{i}\cdot y_{i}-\frac{P(P-1)}{2}}{PN} (6)

where yiâˆˆ{0,1}subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–01y_{i}\in\{0,1\} is the ground-truth label for instance iğ‘–i (with ranking score risubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–r_{i}). The time complexity of this method is Oâ€‹(Mâ€‹logâ¡M)ğ‘‚ğ‘€ğ‘€O(M\log M).

Appendix P Estimate Ï€â€²superscriptğœ‹â€²\pi^{\prime}

Suppose we observe MÂ¯Â¯ğ‘€\bar{M} positive examples and NÂ¯Â¯ğ‘\bar{N} negative examples in the corrupted data Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}. We have:

Pâ€²+Nâ€²=PÂ¯+NÂ¯,Pâ€²â€‹(1âˆ’Ï+)+Nâ€‹Ïâˆ’=PÂ¯formulae-sequencesuperscriptğ‘ƒâ€²superscriptğ‘â€²Â¯ğ‘ƒÂ¯ğ‘superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²1subscriptğœŒğ‘subscriptğœŒÂ¯ğ‘ƒP^{\prime}+N^{\prime}=\bar{P}+\bar{N},\quad P^{\prime}(1-\rho_{+})+N\rho_{-}=\bar{P} (10)

We then obtain:

Appendix R Privacy Analysis of Prediction Scores

In this section, we talk about how clients know the ranking results of their prediction scores and the corresponding privacy issue.

In the vanilla setting, each client Cksubscriptğ¶ğ‘˜C_{k} can send its shuffled prediction scores sksuperscriptğ‘ ğ‘˜s^{k} to the server. The server then aggregates all the prediction scores and sort them in an increasing order. Each prediction score siksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘˜s_{i}^{k} (iâˆˆ[1,M]ğ‘–1ğ‘€i\in[1,M]) will be assigned a ranking order riksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘˜r_{i}^{k}. The instance with the highest order will be assigned r=Mâˆ’1ğ‘Ÿğ‘€1r=M-1, and the second highest one will be assigned Mâˆ’2ğ‘€2M-2 and so on. The smallest ranking score is r=0ğ‘Ÿ0r=0. The server sends each ranking order riksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘˜r_{i}^{k} back to the corresponding client Cksubscriptğ¶ğ‘˜C_{k} which owns siksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘˜s_{i}^{k}. Itâ€™s worth mentioning the prediction scores have to be shared with the server for some tasks. For example, the clients have to report the predicted conversion rate (CVR) of the ad impression to the server in online advertisements. The server 121212ad exchange can later on calculate the bid price by multiplying the predicted CVR with a constant parameter tuned according to the campaign budget and performance Â [23]. Then the server can select the advertiser who proposed the highest bid price as the winner to show the ad.

Interested readers maybe curious is it possible to infer the label information based on the prediction scores. Here we propose a simple attack method by selecting the samples with top-K prediction scores as positive labels. We measure the corresponding guessing performance by precision and recall. As shown in Figure Â 7 and Table Â 8, positive instances can have a relative higher prediction scores than negative ones at some density areas. For example, we can achieve a 79%percent7979\% precision if we select the instances with top-100100100 prediction scores. However, since the prediction scores sksuperscriptğ‘ ğ‘˜s^{k} are shuffled before sending to the server so that the server has no idea which prediction score belongs to which data sample 131313|sk|â‰¥2superscriptğ‘ ğ‘˜2|s^{k}|\geq 2.

Instead of the vanilla setting, we also propose some alternative solutions to achieve the sorting goal. We may leverage DP to add noise to the prediction scores. Since the prediction score is the output of a softmax/sigmoid function, the corresponding sensitivity Î”=1Î”1\Delta=1. We can then leverage Gaussian or Laplace mechanism to add noise to the prediction scores. The corresponding results can be seen in Table Â 9. We can observe that the utility of the computed AUC is highly sensitive to the privacy budget. We cannot achieve a reasonable AUC utility with a small Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon (i.e. Ïµâ‰¤10italic-Ïµ10\epsilon\leq 10).

To achieve both privacy and utility, we can leverage secure multi-party computation (MPC) technique Â [15, 13] to achieve the sorting goal. For example, Hamada et al. Â [13] constructed a quicksort protocol from the quicksort algorithm with their MPC sorting protocol. The resultant protocol can sort 323232-bit words and 1,000,00010000001,000,000 secret-shared values in 1,22712271,227 seconds, while existing sorting protocols cannot sort within 3,60036003,600 seconds.

In this paper, we adopt the vanilla setting to describe our AUC computation technique by default, since the prediction scores are shared between the server and clients. MPC based sorting protocol can replace our vanilla sorting method if necessary (privacy of prediction scores is a concern).

Appendix T Computation resources

We conduct our experiments over a Macbook Pro with 2.4 GHz 8-Core Intel Core i9 and 64 GB 2667 MHz DDR4. Each epoch of run of Criteo takes about 2.5 minutes.
